results.title: Mein kampf = My struggle
results.creator_credit: Minerva International, Tore Sjoberg and Erwin Leiser
results.brief_description: A documentary tracing the rise of the Nazi Party in Germany. The National Socialists effectively utilised film, radio and spectacle in order to create a propaganda involving the majority of Aryan, German-speaking people: a vast theatre of fascism and racism. The film traces the philosophical development of Hitler, as well as the history of World War II (including footage on the occupation of Poland, Czechoslavakia and France, and footage of the decisive battles of Stalingrad and Normandy). The most devastating material explores the fate of the Jewish people under Nazi occupation, including footage of the Warsaw Ghetto and the concentration camps where millions of Jews, political prisoners and “social deviants” were incarcerated and exterminated. It is the power of the stark black and white visuals which fully expose the inhumanity that underlied Nazi philosophy. WARNING: THIS VIDEO FEATURES DISTURBING AND CONFRONTING FOOTAGE OF WAR CRIMES PERPETUATED BY THE NAZI REGIME.

results.title: Megalopolis: cradle of the future
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Irving Rusinow
results.brief_description: Examines the life and problems of Megalopolis, the urbanized northeastern seaboard extending from Boston to Washington, D. C. Shows metropolitan centers, transportation networks, harbors, suburban and rural areas; points out the need for better organization of the suburban sprawl in the future course of urbanization. Compares population density in this region between 1940 and 1960. Also discusses pollution and water contamination and the cultural and economic diversity of the area. Based on the survey ‘Megalopolis: the urbanized northeasteren seaboard of the United States’ by Professor Jean Gottmann from the University of Paris. Narrated by Ben Grauer.

results.title: Megalomedia
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Robin Hughes and Bruce Petty

results.title: Meetings, bloody meetings (NP)
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the disciplines and management techniques that can be used to make meetings shorter and more productive. Intended for all levels of management. Features John Cleese as the Chairman with Timothy West and Angela Down. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Meeting Venus
results.creator_credit: Enigma, Warner Bros Pictures, David Puttnam and Istvan Szabo
results.brief_description: Based on a play co-written by director Istvan Szabo (Mephisto, Sunshine), “Meeting Venus” is set among the elite European opera community. Zoltan Szanto (Niels Arestrup) is a Hungarian conductor hired to direct a daring new interpretation of the Wagner masterpiece “Tannhauser”. Szanto experiences the stigma of being from the East from the moment he arrives in Paris - the Cold War it seems, still rages in officialdom. The film tracks the problems that Szanto encounters trying to conduct an opera with a crew from a dozen countries, each person with idiosyncratic cultural requirements. Complications ensue as cast members press their union demands upon Szanto, who tries to smooth rehearsals with excessive diplomacy. Additional pressures from television crews, financial backers and nervous patrons throw the course of the production into chaos. Despite the personal and creative differences between Szanto and his star attraction - famous Swedish soprano Karin Anderson - the two form a romantic entanglement. Filmed in Budapest, “Meeting Venus” is a comedy that satirises the opera world and the notion of a united Europe. Kiri Te Kanawa provides the singing voice for actress Glenn Close.

results.title: Meeting the needs of adolescents
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
This film describes some of the ways in which parents may help prepare their children for adulthood. It deals with a family which includes a seventeen-year-old girl and a fourteen-year-old boy. It shows how their basic physical needs are met, how they are guided in their spiritual growth, and how parents can develop the social consciousness which will service to aid their children in making a satisfactory adjustment in later life. The film points out what parents can do to help constructively and indicates some of the needless worries that parents have about their teenagers.

results.title: Meeting strangers: red light, green light
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media, Justin M. Purchin and William Brose
results.brief_description: Child molestation is a serious problem. This film will help the child to understand what to do when meeting potentially dangerous strangers. Examples include adult seeking personal information, driver asking child to help him find the way, stranger offering food or gifts, and a false repairman trying to gain entry into the home. The film does not frighten children or encourage a distrustful attitude toward all strangers. However, the point is made that there are some people who would do them harm and who might be difficult to recognize because they look and sound “nice”. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Meeting people is easy [A Film about Radiohead]
results.brief_description: Grant Gee accompanies Radiohead - Colin Greenwood, Ed O’Brien, Jonny Greenwood, Thom Yorke and Philip Selway on their 1997-98 world tour following the success of “OK Computer” with images in keeping with the eclectic and cutting edge style synonymous with the band. Still images overlay live footage and competing noises of the band themselves, interviewers and critics, screaming fans and street sounds. Includes extensive footage of the band in concert across the world with lead singer Thom Yorke posing an alienated figure head, sometimes not even required to sing the songs that have been taken over by adoring fans who know them by heart and the hype surrounding the band as an entity. Shot on tour buses, photo shoots, taxis and hotel rooms, in black and white and colour, the band accused of creating an album to “slash your wrists to” share their thoughts on being celebrities, radio, and the integrity of modern rock sacrificed at the expense of advertising. The motif of transport and the frenetic pace at which the image changes effectively conveys the inability of the band to stop and reflect their wave of success. At times amusing, the documentary does present the lighter sides to being a famous band, such as being rejected from their own party because the bouncers didn’t recognise them.

results.title: Meeting in session
results.creator_credit: Columbia University Teahcer's College Bureau of Publications and Josef Bohmer
results.brief_description: Glimpses of a variety of meetings - a school faculty, a high school committee, a business men’s session, a committee of nurses - illustrate the fact that most of us work in groups from time to time. Two contrasting session are presented, as a small group of nurses attempts to solve the problem of adequate staffing for the hospital four to twelve shift. In each meeting the problem and the participants are the same. The differences are in general approach, attitude displayed, techniques used and results achieved. In the first meeting participants enact negative roles characteristic of individuals intent on their own feelings and problems. The supervisor is an impatient administrator; head nurses demand rigid interpretation of present rules. In the second meeting nurses assume the roles of co-operative group members interested in desirable solutions and sympathetically aware of each other’s feelings. Each member contributes, and her ideas receive thoughtful consideration. At the end the nurse-recorder sums up suggestions, and each person volunteers for work on one or more specific proposals.

results.title: Meeting in Progress
results.creator_credit: Roundtable Productions, Leon S. Gold and Arthur Swerdloff
results.brief_description: This is a management training film that looks at the role of a conference leader who is responsible for the ultimate achievement of the purpose of the meeting. The realistic setting for the film is a staff meeting led by a department manager and attend by other staff members. This fictional meeting demonstrates critical points typical of any meeting and it gives solutions.
